abstract_summ: There are few known cases of Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS) related to SARS-CoV-2 infection; we propose this case as a rare variant of GBS in COVID-19 infection context, due to Its chronology, clinical manifestations and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) findings.Neurologic manifestations of the disease are increasingly identified and this will help clinician to improve their diagnostic and therapeutic skills in dealing with COVID-19 patients.Although pulmonary manifestations are more common, patients with severe disease may present with neurological symptoms such as in our case.As the COVID-19 pandemic evolves, the medical community continues to discover novel clinical manifestations of the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) virus.As our knowledge of this disease evolves, surgeons need to remain suspicious for possible gastrointestinal manifestations of COVID-19.
title_summ: Extrapulmonary Gastrointestinal Presentation of Coronavirus (COVID-19): A Case Report and Review of LiteratureGuillain-Barré syndrome following COVID-19: a newly emerging post-infectious complicationFacial diplegia, a possible atypical variant of Guillain-Barré Syndrome as a rare neurological complication of SARS-CoV-2Intussusception in an infant as a manifestation of COVID-19Rhabdomyolysis as a manifestation of a severe case of COVID-19: A Case ReportGuillain-Barré syndrome in a patient infected with SARS-CoV-2, a case reportCoronavirus Disease 2019 (Covid-19) presenting as purulent fulminant myopericarditis and cardiac tamponade: a case report and literature review.Acute Effusive Pericarditis: A Late Complication of COVID-19COVID-19-Associated Bifacial Weakness with Paresthesia Subtype of Guillain-Barré Syndrome.COVID-19-Associated Miller Fisher Syndrome: MRI Findings.Asymptomatic COVID-19: What the Neuroradiologist Needs to Know about Pulmonary Manifestations.
title_abstract_phrases: Neurologic manifestations of the disease are increasingly identified and this will help clinician to improve their diagnostic and therapeutic skills in dealing with COVID-19 patients.There are few known cases of Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS) related to SARS-CoV-2 infection; we propose this case as a rare variant of GBS in COVID-19 infection context, due to Its chronology, clinical manifestations and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) findings.Rhabdomyolysis as a manifestation of a severe case of COVID-19: A Case ReportSince the outbreak of the ongoing pandemic of the novel coronavirus disease (COVID-19) in Wuhan, China, from December 2019, we have learned that multiple organs can be affected with the potential for various complications.Guillain-Barré syndrome in a patient infected with SARS-CoV-2, a case reportBACKGROUND: The COVID-19 is a novel condition affecting all the world, so every manifestation of disease should be reported.Although pulmonary manifestations are more common, patients with severe disease may present with neurological symptoms such as in our case.
